title: Monitoring Beginner Quiz
description: Master the fundamentals of monitoring, metrics, logging, alerting, and observability concepts for effective system health management

questions.title: Purpose of Monitoring
questions.description: What is the primary purpose of monitoring in a production system?
questions.situation: Your team is launching a new web application. Your manager asks why you need to implement monitoring.
options: To track user behavior and sell data to advertisers
To make colorful dashboards for presentations
To detect problems early, ensure system health, and make informed decisions
To replace the need for testing and quality assurance
questions.explanation: Monitoring helps detect issues before they impact users, ensures systems are healthy and performing well, and provides data for capacity planning and optimization. It's a proactive approach to system reliability.
questions.hint: Think about preventing downtime and maintaining service quality.

questions.title: CPU Metrics
questions.description: Your web server's CPU usage is consistently at 95%. What does this indicate?
questions.situation: You check your monitoring dashboard and notice the CPU metric showing 95% utilization for the past hour.
options: The system is working perfectly and efficiently
The server is likely overloaded and may need scaling or optimization
This is normal for all web servers
You should immediately restart the server
questions.explanation: Sustained high CPU usage (above 80-90%) typically indicates the server is struggling to handle the load. This can lead to slow response times, timeouts, and poor user experience. You should investigate the cause and consider scaling or optimization.
questions.hint: High CPU usage over extended periods usually signals a problem.

questions.title: Memory Usage
questions.description: Which metric indicates how much RAM is actively being used by applications?
questions.situation: You're setting up monitoring for a new application server and need to track memory consumption.
options: Disk space
CPU load average
Network bandwidth
Memory usage / RAM utilization
questions.explanation: Memory usage or RAM utilization tracks how much of your system's memory is being used by running processes. High memory usage can lead to swapping, performance degradation, or out-of-memory errors.
questions.hint: Think about where applications store their running data.

questions.title: Disk Space Alerts
questions.description: At what disk usage percentage should you typically set an alert?
questions.situation: You're configuring disk space monitoring for your database server. You want to be notified before running out of space.
options: 50% - alert when half full
70-80% - provide time to investigate and take action
99% - wait until the last moment
25% - alert when mostly empty
questions.explanation: Setting alerts at 70-80% disk usage gives you adequate warning time to investigate log growth, clean up unnecessary files, or add more storage before critical issues occur. Waiting until 99% is too late.
questions.hint: You need enough advance warning to take action before it's critical.

questions.title: Network Monitoring
questions.description: Which metric measures the amount of data transferred over the network?
questions.situation: Your application seems slow, and you suspect network issues. Which metric should you check?
options: Disk IOPS
Memory usage
CPU percentage
Network bandwidth / throughput
questions.explanation: Network bandwidth or throughput measures how much data is being transferred over the network. High usage can indicate legitimate traffic spikes, DDoS attacks, or misconfigured applications sending excessive data.
questions.hint: Think about data moving across the network.

questions.title: Logging vs Monitoring
questions.description: What is the key difference between logging and monitoring?
questions.situation: Your team is discussing whether to implement logging or monitoring for the new application.
options: Monitoring is free; logging costs money
They are exactly the same thing with different names
Logging is for developers; monitoring is only for operations
Logging records discrete events; monitoring tracks metrics over time
questions.explanation: Logging captures specific events and messages (like errors, user actions, or transactions), while monitoring tracks numerical metrics over time (like CPU usage, request rates, or response times). Both are essential and complementary.
questions.hint: Think about the type of data each one collects - events vs. numbers.

questions.title: Alert Configuration
questions.description: What makes a good alerting rule?
questions.situation: You're setting up your first alerts for a production system. What should you prioritize?
options: Only alert the CEO directly for maximum visibility
Alert on every single metric change to catch everything
Alert only on actionable issues that require immediate attention
Never set up alerts - check dashboards manually every hour
questions.explanation: Good alerts are actionable (require human intervention), important (affect users or business), and have clear ownership. Too many alerts cause alert fatigue, while too few mean missing critical issues.
questions.hint: Think about avoiding noise while catching real problems.

questions.title: Health Check Endpoints
questions.description: What is a health check endpoint in a web application?
questions.situation: You're deploying an API service and need to set up monitoring. The documentation mentions implementing a health check endpoint.
options: A security feature to scan for viruses
An endpoint that returns the application's operational status
A page that shows employee health insurance information
A backup system for data recovery
questions.explanation: A health check endpoint (typically /health or /healthz) is a simple URL that returns whether the application is running properly. Monitoring systems regularly check this endpoint to verify the service is alive and responding.
questions.hint: Think about how you can quickly verify if a service is working.

questions.title: Uptime Monitoring
questions.situation: Your SLA promises 99.9% uptime. Your manager asks how much downtime is acceptable per month.
options: About 7 hours per month
About 43 minutes per month
About 3.65 days per year
No downtime ever allowed
questions.explanation: 99.9% uptime (three nines) means the service can be down for approximately 0.1% of the time. Per month (30 days), this equals about 43.2 minutes of acceptable downtime. 99.99% (four nines) would be about 4.3 minutes per month.
questions.hint: Calculate 0.1% of a month (30 days × 24 hours × 60 minutes).

questions.title: Monitoring Tools
questions.description: Which tool is commonly used for time-series metrics and monitoring?
questions.situation: Your team needs to choose a monitoring solution for tracking CPU, memory, and application metrics over time.
options: Git
Prometheus
Slack
Microsoft Word
questions.explanation: Prometheus is a popular open-source monitoring system designed for collecting and storing time-series data. It's widely used with Grafana for visualization. Other popular options include Datadog, New Relic, and CloudWatch.
questions.hint: Think about dedicated monitoring and metrics platforms.

questions.title: Dashboard Design
questions.description: What should a good monitoring dashboard display?
questions.situation: You're creating your first monitoring dashboard for your team. What information is most important?
options: Key metrics that indicate system health and performance
Only colorful graphs to impress management
Every possible metric available in the system
Personal information about team members
questions.explanation: Effective dashboards focus on the most important metrics (KPIs) that indicate system health, like error rates, response times, throughput, and resource usage. They should be clear, actionable, and not overwhelming with unnecessary information.
questions.hint: Less is more - focus on what matters most.

questions.title: SLA Understanding
questions.description: What is an SLA (Service Level Agreement)?
questions.situation: You're joining a new team and hear them discussing SLAs. What are they talking about?
options: A type of software license
A team lunch schedule agreement
A commitment to a specific level of service quality and availability
A security audit checklist
questions.explanation: An SLA is a formal commitment between a service provider and customer defining expected service levels, typically including uptime guarantees, response times, and support availability. Violating SLAs can result in penalties or refunds.
questions.hint: Think about promises made to customers about service quality.

questions.title: Response Time Monitoring
questions.description: Why is monitoring API response time important?
questions.situation: Your API is working without errors, but users are complaining. You check the response time metric and see it's 5 seconds per request.
options: Response time doesn't matter as long as requests eventually complete
5 seconds is fast enough for any application
Slow response times lead to poor user experience and potential timeouts
Response time only matters for mobile applications
questions.explanation: Response time directly impacts user experience. Slow responses frustrate users, can cause timeouts, and may indicate performance issues like database bottlenecks, inefficient code, or resource constraints. Most APIs should respond in milliseconds to a few seconds.
questions.hint: Think about user experience and performance expectations.

questions.title: Error Rate Metrics
questions.description: What does an increasing error rate indicate?
questions.situation: Your monitoring dashboard shows the error rate climbing from 0.1% to 5% over the last hour.
options: Indicates a problem that needs immediate investigation
This is normal fluctuation - ignore it
Users are making mistakes - provide better documentation
The monitoring system is broken
questions.explanation: A sudden increase in error rate typically signals a problem: recent code deployment issues, infrastructure problems, dependency failures, or increased load causing failures. This requires immediate investigation to prevent widespread user impact.
questions.hint: Sudden changes in error rates are usually bad signs.

questions.title: Log Severity Levels
questions.description: Which log level should you use for recording errors that need attention?
questions.situation: Your application encounters a database connection failure. What log level should this be recorded at?
options: ERROR
INFO
DEBUG
TRACE
questions.explanation: ERROR level is for problems that need attention but don't crash the application. DEBUG is for detailed diagnostic info, INFO is for general informational messages, and TRACE is for very detailed debugging. FATAL/CRITICAL is for application-stopping errors.
questions.hint: Think about the severity of a database connection failure.

questions.title: Observability Basics
questions.description: What are the three pillars of observability?
questions.situation: Your team is implementing observability practices. What should you focus on?
options: Development, staging, and production
CPU, memory, and disk
Frontend, backend, and database
Logs, metrics, and traces
questions.explanation: The three pillars of observability are: Logs (discrete events), Metrics (numerical data over time), and Traces (request flows through distributed systems). Together they provide comprehensive insight into system behavior.
questions.hint: Think about the different types of data that help you understand system behavior.

questions.title: Alert Fatigue
questions.description: What is alert fatigue and why is it problematic?
questions.situation: Your team receives 50 alerts per day, but most aren't critical. Engineers start ignoring alerts.
options: When alerts are too quiet and people fall asleep
When the monitoring system gets tired and stops working
When too many non-critical alerts cause teams to ignore all alerts
A medical condition from working too many on-call shifts
questions.explanation: Alert fatigue occurs when teams receive too many alerts, especially false positives or low-priority notifications. This leads to desensitization where critical alerts are missed or ignored. Solution: create clear, actionable alerts and reduce noise.
questions.hint: Think about the boy who cried wolf - what happens with too many false alarms?

questions.title: Data Retention
questions.description: Why do monitoring systems typically aggregate older metrics data?
questions.situation: Your Prometheus setup keeps high-resolution data for 15 days but aggregates older data into hourly summaries.
options: To confuse engineers looking at historical data
To save storage space while maintaining historical trends
Because old data is less important and should be deleted
Aggregation happens automatically and can't be controlled
questions.explanation: Storing every data point forever would require enormous storage. Aggregation (downsampling) reduces granularity for older data while preserving trends. For example, keeping 1-minute resolution for 30 days, then hourly for a year, provides useful history without excessive storage costs.
questions.hint: Think about balancing storage costs with useful historical information.
